channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: China to Implement Export Controls on Some Steel Products
item.description: Officials said exporters would need permission to ship any of 300 specified steel products starting Jan. 1.

item.title: U.K. Economy Contracts Again, Likely Cementing BOE Rate Cut
item.description: Economic activity dipped 0.1% on month in October. Economists polled by The Wall Street Journal had expected an increase.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: The Federal Reserve’s board of governors voted unanimously to reappoint 11 reserve bank presidents to new five-year terms beginning March 1, 2026
item.description: The reappointment process had always been an under-the-radar administrative process that didn’t attract attention—until this year.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: China urged Mexico to rectify “unilateral, protectionist practices,” saying that tariffs of up to 50% announced by the Latin American country harm Chinese interests
item.description: Lawmakers pass levies targeting countries that Mexico has no trade agreement with, including China.
item.dc:creator: Santiago Pérez

item.title: Canada Swings to Modest Goods-Trade Surplus in September
item.description: Canada logged its first trade surplus in eight months in September as exports rebounded and domestic demand showed signs of softening.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: The U.S. trade deficit narrowed to its lowest level in five years in September, U.S. figures show, mostly because investors moved gold back overseas after a run-up in imports of the precious metal
item.description: U.S. investors had stockpiled gold from abroad in the spring, fearing steep tariffs. But the tariffs never came, and the trade reversed.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Jobless Claims Rose Last Week but Remained Modest
item.description: The number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits rose last week but stayed well within the range that has prevailed over the past year.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Turkish Central Bank Cuts Rates Again Despite Inflation Risks
item.description: The central bank cut its benchmark rate to 38.0% from 39.5% on Thursday, but noted lingering risks for consumer prices.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: Philippine Central Bank Cuts Rates Again as Economy’s Outlook Withers
item.description: Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas delivered a fifth straight rate cut at its final meeting of the year in a widely expected move.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Lee

item.title: Swiss National Bank Holds Key Interest Rate at 0%
item.description: Switzerland’s central bank again left its key interest rate unchanged, but signaled it was open to a further cut that would take it below zero.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: ECB Unlikely to Follow Fed For Now, But Currency Moves May Yet Prove Decisive
item.description: Policymakers in Europe may face growing pressure to also lower interest rates if the pace of easing significantly weakens the dollar.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: President Trump wants lower interest rates and a new Fed chair. Wednesday’s divisions suggest one won’t guarantee the other.
item.description: President Trump wants lower interest rates and a new Fed chair. Wednesday’s divisions suggest one won’t guarantee the other.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: Fed Chair Jerome Powell said that Fed staffers believe federal data could be overstating job creation by up to 60,000 jobs a month—which suggests the jobs market might be shrinking
item.description: Powell said that Fed staffers believe federal data could be overstating job creation by up to 60,000 jobs a month—which suggests the jobs market might be shrinking.
item.dc:creator: Harriet Torry

item.title: Global Trade Flows Show Surprising Strength Despite Strain Of Higher U.S. Tariffs
item.description: However, trade is likely to come under increased strain if goods that China can no longer sell to U.S. consumers flood other markets at knock-down prices.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Layoffs crept higher in recent months, but the job market remained fundamentally steady since the summer, the Labor Department reported Tuesday
item.description: The Labor Department’s JOLTS survey shows rate of layoffs ticked up to 1.2% in October versus 1.1% in August.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Weekly ADP Update Suggests Private Companies Added Jobs
item.description: Private companies grew their payrolls slightly on net through much of November, human-resources firm ADP said.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: German Exports Inched Up in October Despite U.S. Weakness
item.description: The result was driven by resilient demand for goods from within the EU, which offset a tariff-impacted slowdown in exports to the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: The historic milestone comes as China adds high-end manufacturing strength to its established dominance in lower-end goods, fueling trade tensions
item.description: The historic milestone comes as China adds high-end manufacturing strength to its established dominance in lower-end goods.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Cheng

item.title: U.S. households are nearing the end of the year feeling more dour about the economy than they did at the beginning, even as they keep spending
item.description: Sentiment has neared record lows, even as spending is continuing.
item.dc:creator: Chao Deng

item.title: China is pursuing a “beggar thy neighbor” growth model at everyone else’s expense, writes WSJ’s Greg Ip
item.description: China is swallowing up a growing share of the world’s market for manufactured goods, revealing an uncomfortable truth: Beijing is pursuing a “beggar thy neighbor” growth model at everyone else’s expense.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: Monthly index of consumer sentiment for December from the University of Michigan rose slightly versus November, but remained much lower than where it began the year
item.description: Monthly index of consumer sentiment from the University of Michigan rose slightly versus November, but remained much lower than where it began the year.
item.dc:creator: Chao Deng

item.title: Eurozone Economy Posts Stronger Growth on Investment Rebound
item.description: The economy grew at a faster pace than estimated in the three months through September, aided by a pickup in investment.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Jobless Claims Fell to New Recent Low Per Labor Department
item.description: Newly filed unemployment claims last week dropped to the lowest level in three years, the Labor Department said, a reassuring signal the economy avoided a big surge of layoffs through the first 11 months of the year.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Growth to Slow as Tariffs Bite, but AI Investments May Cushion the Blow
item.description: The OECD forecast the global economy to expand by 2.9% next year, a slowdown from 3.2% this year.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.S. manufacturing activity contracted for the ninth consecutive month in November, a decline manufacturers attribute largely to President Trump’s tariffs
item.description: Tariffs, which have increased costs for sourcing materials, continue to weigh on U.S. producers.
item.dc:creator: Chao Deng

item.title: China Private Gauge Signals Weaker Manufacturing Activity
item.description: Growth in China’s manufacturing production came to a halt as new orders nearly stalled last month despite a renewed rise in new orders from abroad.

item.title: More than other generations, 20-somethings are tightening their year-end spending. Here is why that is a problem for retail brands.
item.description: More than other generations, 20-somethings are tightening their holiday-season budgets because of economic pressures.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Williams

item.title: U.K. Home Sales Fall on Budget Uncertainty, Report Says
item.description: Sales fell 4% across the U.K., with buyer demand down 12% on year on fears of higher property taxes in the budget, according to a report by real-estate agency Zoopla.
item.dc:creator: Ian Walker

item.title: Shutdown-delayed data showed American consumers closed out the third quarter on a cautious footing, while a measure of consumer confidence tumbled in November
item.description: American consumers in September reined in spending on tariff-hit categories such as vehicles, electronics and clothing.
item.dc:creator: Harriet Torry

item.title: U.S. Home Prices Slow Further Amid Affordability Concerns
item.description: The S&P Cotality Case-Shiller National Home Price Index, which measures home prices across the country, rose 1.3% in the 12 months through September. This represents the weakest performance since mid-2023.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: Parts of Europe at Risk of Downward ‘Spiral’ if Older Voters Stymie Reforms, EBRD Warns
item.description: Economies that escaped from Communism are at risk if older voters and political leaders prevent changes to offset aging populations.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Thanksgiving might actually be cheaper this year
item.description: Turkey, stuffing and cranberry prices are all lower, but skip the yams. Sweet potato prices have skyrocketed.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Kuo

item.title: Home sales rose to an eight-month high in October, signaling how even a small decline in mortgage rates will attract some buyers back to the market
item.description: Falling mortgage rates spurred more activity in the beleaguered housing market, with sales moving higher for the second consecutive month.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: Threats to Eurozone Financial Stability ‘Remain Elevated,’ Says ECB’s De Guindos
item.description: A large-scale trade war has been averted, but uncertainty remains high about government policies that can affect the financial system, the European Central Bank vice president said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Heard on the Street: Borrowing from a builder might get you an eye-catching mortgage rate, but it also means you are more likely to overpay and potentially end up underwater
item.description: Borrowing from a builder might get buyers an eye-catching mortgage rate, but it also means they are more likely to overpay for the property—and potentially end up underwater.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan

item.title: Heard on the Street: New homes are sitting unsold, despite the discounted mortgages that builders are offering
item.description: New homes are sitting unsold, despite builders using sweeteners to shift inventory.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan
